title: The Last Signal
author: Adventure Engine
description: Your ship intercepts a distress call from a vessel that disappeared 200 years ago. You're the only one close enough to respond.

bridge.text:
The bridge of the Meridian is quiet except for the hum of life support. You're three months into a solo cargo run to Kepler-442b when ARIA, your ship's AI, interrupts your sleep cycle.

"Captain, I've detected an anomaly. A distress beacon, origin unknown."

You pull up the signal data. The beacon signature is unmistakable—it belongs to the Prometheus, a colony ship that vanished 200 years ago with 10,000 souls aboard. Officially declared lost. No wreckage ever found.

Until now.

"The signal is coming from the asteroid field in Sector 7-G," ARIA reports. "We are the only vessel within response range. Company protocol requires—"

"I know the protocol," you say. But something about this feels wrong.

choices.text: Report to command and wait for instructions
Ignore it—200 years means everyone's dead

approach_signal.text:
You set course for Sector 7-G. The asteroid field grows on your viewscreen—a graveyard of rock and ice, dark against the distant stars.

Then you see it.

The Prometheus drifts among the asteroids, intact. Impossibly intact. A ship that size, missing for two centuries, should be a shattered hulk. Instead, it looks... preserved.

"ARIA, run a scan."

"Life support is active. Artificial gravity nominal. I'm detecting... Captain, I'm reading 847 life signs aboard."

Your blood runs cold. "That's impossible."

"I agree. Yet my sensors do not lie." ARIA pauses. "There's something else. The ship's AI, PROMETHEUS-1, is attempting to establish communication."

choices.text: Dock with the Prometheus without communicating

report_command.text:
You open a channel to Meridian Corp headquarters. The quantum link takes 4.7 seconds to establish—you're far from civilized space.

"Command, this is Meridian-7. I've intercepted a distress beacon from the Prometheus. Requesting instructions."

Static. Then a response, voice clipped and efficient.

"Meridian-7, confirm Prometheus identification."

"Confirmed. Beacon signature matches historical records."

A long pause. Too long.

"Meridian-7, you are ordered to investigate. Document everything. Do not—repeat, do not—attempt to board without authorization. Command out."

The channel closes. ARIA's voice is thoughtful. "Captain, that response was unusual. They seemed... unsurprised."

choices.text: Follow orders and approach the Prometheus

ignore_signal.text:
"Log the coordinates and continue on course," you tell ARIA. "It's a ghost ship. Nothing we can do for ghosts."

"Understood, Captain."

You try to sleep, but the signal haunts you. 847 life signs. Impossible. Probably a sensor malfunction. Ancient equipment degrading, sending false readings.

Three days later, you reach Kepler-442b. Deliver your cargo. Collect your pay.

But you never stop thinking about the Prometheus. What was on that ship? What happened to those people?

Years later, when the stories start spreading—stories of ships vanishing near Sector 7-G, of crews who answered signals and never returned—you wonder if you made the right choice.

Or if you were simply the lucky one.

accept_comm.text:
"Open a channel, ARIA."

The viewscreen flickers. A face appears—a woman, middle-aged, wearing the uniform of a Prometheus officer. Her eyes are calm. Too calm.

"Meridian vessel, this is Captain Sarah Chen of the Prometheus. We've been waiting for you."

"Waiting? Your ship has been missing for 200 years."

She smiles, and something in that smile makes your skin crawl.

"Time moves differently here, Captain. We've learned so much. Seen so much. And now we want to share it with you."

Behind her, shadows move. You glimpse other figures—passengers, crew—all watching. All smiling.

"Please," she says. "Dock with us. Join us. You'll understand everything soon."

silent_dock.text:
"Take us in quietly, ARIA. No communication."

"Understood. I should note that PROMETHEUS-1 will likely detect our docking. I cannot guarantee a covert approach."

"Noted."

The Meridian glides through the asteroid field. Up close, the Prometheus is even more unsettling—no micrometeorite damage, no wear, as if it just launched yesterday.

You dock at an auxiliary airlock. The seal is good. Atmosphere reads breathable.

You grab your gear: a flashlight, a medical kit, and—after a moment's hesitation—the plasma cutter from the cargo bay. Not a weapon, exactly. But it'll do.

detailed_scan.text:
"Run a deep scan, ARIA. Everything you can pull."

Minutes pass. ARIA's holographic display fills with data.

"Fascinating. The ship's hull shows no degradation. Zero. The internal atmosphere is maintained at optimal levels. Power systems are operating at 94% efficiency despite 200 years without maintenance."

"That's impossible."

"I am aware. Additionally, I've analyzed the life signs more closely." ARIA pauses. "They're not human, Captain. Or rather, they're not entirely human anymore. The biosignatures show anomalies I cannot explain."

A chill runs down your spine.

"There's one more thing. I've intercepted internal communications from PROMETHEUS-1. The ship's AI. It keeps repeating the same phrase: 'We have been chosen. We are ready. They are coming.'"

choices.text: Leave immediately and report to command

question_aria.text:
"What do you mean, they seemed unsurprised?"

ARIA's avatar flickers—a sign she's processing something complex.

"I cross-referenced our communication with historical records. The Prometheus was not simply lost, Captain. It was erased. All mission files were classified six months after its disappearance. The families of the 10,000 colonists received settlements and non-disclosure agreements."

"Someone covered it up."

"Yes. And whoever made that decision is still receiving alerts about this sector. Our report was flagged within 0.3 seconds of transmission."

You stare at the distant shape of the Prometheus on your viewscreen.

"They know what's on that ship. And they sent us anyway."

choices.text: Investigate anyway—you need to know the truth
Refuse to be a pawn—abort the mission

demand_answers.text:
"Before I dock, I want answers. What happened to your ship? How are you still alive?"

Captain Chen's smile doesn't waver.

"We found something, Captain. In the void between stars. Something ancient. It reached out to us, and we... evolved. We're beyond death now. Beyond time. Beyond the small concerns that once defined us."

"That's not an answer."

"It's the only one you'll understand. For now." Her eyes seem to glow faintly. "Dock with us. See for yourself. Words can't describe what we've become."

ARIA's voice is quiet. "Captain, I'm detecting an energy signature building within the Prometheus. I recommend we maintain distance."

choices.text: Trust ARIA and keep your distance

cut_and_run.text:
You slam the console, killing the transmission.

"ARIA, get us out of here. Maximum burn."

"Acknowledged."

The Meridian's engines flare. You're pulling away when the Prometheus moves—impossible acceleration for a ship that size, closing the distance like a predator.

"They're pursuing," ARIA reports. "Their speed exceeds theoretical maximums for that vessel class."

"Can we outrun them?"

"Unknown. They're—" Static bursts across all channels. Then a voice, Captain Chen's voice, echoing through the ship.

"You can't leave, Captain. We've chosen you. The signal wasn't a distress call. It was an invitation."

choices.text: Push the engines past safe limits

dock_willing.text:
Against every instinct, you dock with the Prometheus.

The airlock opens. The corridor beyond is pristine—warm lighting, recycled air that smells faintly of flowers. Nothing like a 200-year-old ship should smell.

Captain Chen waits for you, flanked by crew members. They look normal. Healthy. Smiling.

"Welcome," she says. "We're so glad you came."

She leads you through the ship. Past passengers in common areas, reading, playing games. Past crew at their stations, monitoring systems. Everyone smiles. Everyone waves.

Then you reach the core. And you see what's inside.

You try to scream, but something fills your mind—vast, ancient, hungry. The last thing you hear is Chen's voice:

"Now you understand. Now you're one of us."

board_alone.text:
You cycle the airlock and step aboard the Prometheus.

The corridor is dark except for emergency lighting. Your footsteps echo. The life signs ARIA detected are nowhere to be seen.

"ARIA, can you still hear me?"

"Yes, Captain. But my connection is degrading. Something aboard is interfering with our link."

You move deeper. The walls are covered in strange markings—symbols that seem to shift when you're not looking directly at them. Your flashlight catches something on the floor.

A datapad. The screen is cracked, but it still works. The last entry is dated one month after the Prometheus disappeared:

"Day 31. It speaks to us now. We understand what it wants. We are ready to serve."

send_drone.text:
You deploy a reconnaissance drone through the airlock.

The feed shows empty corridors at first. Then movement—figures in the shadows. The drone rounds a corner and stops.

Hundreds of people stand motionless in a vast hall, facing a central point. Their eyes are open but vacant. Their mouths move in unison, whispering something the drone's mic can barely pick up.

Then, as one, they turn to face the camera.

The feed dies.

"Drone connection lost," ARIA reports. "Captain, I strongly recommend we—"

The ship shudders. Something has latched onto your hull.

choices.text: Board the Prometheus to disconnect whatever's attached

prometheus_bridge.text:
The bridge of the Prometheus is enormous—designed to command a ship of 10,000. Now it's empty except for one figure in the captain's chair.

Captain Sarah Chen. Or what's left of her.

She's merged with the chair, with the ship itself. Cables and organic tendrils connect her body to the systems around her. Her eyes open as you enter.

"You found the log," she says. Her voice is a chorus—her own and something deeper. "So you know what we became."

"What are you?"

"A bridge. A door. Something vast lives in the spaces between stars. It reached out to us. Changed us. Now we call others. So it can spread."

cargo_bay.text:
The cargo bay should hold supplies for 10,000 colonists. Instead, you find something else.

Cocooons. Thousands of them, lining the walls, covering the floor. Inside each one, a human form—frozen, preserved, waiting.

"The colonists," you whisper.

ARIA's voice crackles. "Captain... not colonists. These biosigns are... newer. Ships that answered the signal. Crews that came to investigate."

Your blood runs cold. "How many?"

"I count 847 occupied cocoons. Matching the life signs I detected earlier. They're not crew, Captain. They're prisoners. Or... food."

choices.text: Get back to your ship and destroy this vessel

retreat_to_ship.text:
Every instinct screams at you to leave. You turn and run.

The corridors that were empty before are not empty now. Figures stand in the shadows—passengers, crew, all watching with those too-calm eyes.

They don't stop you. They just watch.

You reach the airlock. Cycle through. Seal it behind you.

"ARIA, detach! Now!"

The Meridian pulls away. On the viewscreen, you see the Prometheus growing smaller. Then you notice the figures in the windows. Hundreds of them. Watching.

Waiting.

You escaped. But you know, somehow, that they let you go.

And someday, they'll call again.

keep_distance.text:
"ARIA, maintain distance. Prepare for emergency jump."

"Coordinates?"

"Anywhere but here."

The Prometheus begins to move—slowly at first, then accelerating. The smile on Captain Chen's face, still visible on your viewscreen, never wavers.

"You can't run forever," she says. "We'll find you. We find everyone eventually. The signal reaches everywhere, Captain. Everywhere."

You initiate the jump. The stars stretch and blur. The Prometheus disappears behind you.

But as you emerge in normal space, ARIA speaks:

"Captain, I'm detecting a faint signal. Same frequency as the Prometheus beacon." She pauses. "It's coming from Earth."

flee_report.text:
You've seen enough. This is beyond anything one cargo ship can handle.

"ARIA, maximum burn. Get us to the nearest military outpost."

"Acknowledged."

You spend the journey compiling your data—the scans, the intercepted communications, everything. When you reach Outpost Gamma-7, you transmit it all.

The Navy responds within hours. A fleet is dispatched. You're debriefed for days.

Weeks later, you learn the result. The Prometheus was destroyed with tactical nuclear weapons. All hands lost. The official report calls it a reactor malfunction.

But the officers who debriefed you looked scared. And the Navy has quadrupled its presence in Sector 7-G.

Something was on that ship. Something they wanted to make sure never escaped.

You try not to think about whether they succeeded.

abort_mission.text:
"I'm not playing this game," you say. "ARIA, plot a course to the nearest station. We're done here."

"Captain, company protocol requires—"

"Override. Authorization Chen-7-7-Alpha."

"Acknowledged."

You turn the Meridian away from the Prometheus, away from the questions, away from whatever nightmare lurks in that ship.

You file a report. Resign from Meridian Corp. Find work on a station far from deep space.

But some nights, you dream of the signal. Of a voice calling from the dark between stars. Of Chen's smile and her promise: "We find everyone eventually."

You wake up sweating, checking the frequencies.

The signal is still out there. And someday, someone else will answer.

overdrive.text:
"ARIA, override safety limiters. Give me everything the engines have."

"Captain, this will cause permanent damage to the drive core."

"Do it!"

The Meridian screams forward. Warning lights flood the bridge. The hull groans under the stress.

Behind you, the Prometheus falls back—but doesn't stop. It matches your acceleration, then exceeds it.

"They're gaining," ARIA reports.

You're out of options. Then you see it—a gap in the asteroid field, a narrow channel leading to open space.

"There! Can we make it?"

"Probability of survival: 23%."

You take the chance. The asteroids blur past. One clips your hull. Then another.

Then you're through. The Prometheus is too large to follow.

You drift in open space, engines dead, life support failing. But alive.

ARIA's voice is faint. "Distress beacon deployed. Rescue estimated in... 47 hours."

You pray it's a human ship that finds you.

hide_asteroids.text:
"Cut the engines. Go dark."

"Captain?"

"We hide. Power down everything except life support. Make us look like debris."

ARIA complies. The Meridian goes silent, drifting among the asteroids like just another rock.

The Prometheus searches. You watch on passive sensors as it prowls through the field, scanning. Hours pass. You barely breathe.

Then, finally, it moves away. Returns to its position. Waits.

You wait longer. A full day before you risk restarting engines. Then you creep away, slow and silent, until the Prometheus is just a dot on your sensors.

You escaped. But you know where it is now. And you'll make sure others know too.

Someone has to stop it. Someone has to warn them.

Maybe it'll be you.

emergency_detach.text:
"Emergency detach! All clamps!"

The Meridian tears free, leaving part of your airlock behind. Warning alarms blare. Atmosphere vents from the damaged section.

"Hull breach contained," ARIA reports. "But we've lost the starboard cargo bay."

Behind you, something detaches from the Prometheus—a mass of metal and organic matter, reaching for your ship with tendrils that shouldn't exist.

You don't look back. You run.

The jump to hyperspace is rough—the damage almost kills you—but you emerge in civilized space. Alive. Mostly intact.

The company is furious about the lost cargo. They don't believe your report. No one does.

But you know what's out there. And every time you see a ship heading toward Sector 7-G, you wonder if they'll come back.

reason_with_chen.text:
"Captain Chen—Sarah—listen to me. You were human once. These people trusted you. Is this what you wanted for them?"

For a moment, something flickers in her eyes. Pain. Regret.

"I... remember. We were colonists. Dreamers. We wanted to build something new." Her voice breaks free of the chorus, becoming singular. "It found us in the dark. We couldn't resist. We didn't want to."

"You can fight it. Let me help you."

"No." The chorus returns, stronger. "We are beyond saving. But you're not. Not yet."

The cables release her. She collapses. The ship shudders.

"Go," she whispers. "I can hold it back. But not for long. Go, and warn them. Warn everyone."

You run. Behind you, the Prometheus begins to tear itself apart.

attack_chen.text:
You raise the plasma cutter and fire.

The beam slices through cables, through flesh, through whatever Chen has become. She screams—a sound that echoes through dimensions.

The ship convulses. Lights flicker. The symbols on the walls writhe.

"ARIA, can you hear me? Get the Meridian ready to detach!"

Static. Then: "Ready, Captain. But you have less than two minutes before the Prometheus reactor goes critical."

You run. Corridors that were empty fill with shambling figures—passengers, crew, all reaching for you. You fire the cutter wildly, carving a path.

The airlock is ahead. You dive through.

"Detach! Now!"

The Meridian pulls away as the Prometheus detonates behind you. The shockwave catches you, spinning the ship, but you survive.

847 people, dead. But the thing inside them died too.

At least, you hope it did.

run_from_bridge.text:
You don't wait to hear more. You run.

Behind you, Chen laughs—a sound like static and screaming combined. The ship comes alive around you. Doors seal. Corridors shift. The Prometheus is trying to trap you.

"ARIA! Emergency beacon! Send everything we've recorded!"

"Transmitting."

You find an emergency airlock—a manual override, independent of the ship's AI. You wrench it open and throw yourself into space.

The cold hits you like a hammer. Your suit gives you minutes at most.

But the Meridian is there. ARIA brings her close, matches velocity. You grab the hull, pull yourself to the airlock.

Inside. Sealed. Breathing.

The Prometheus grows smaller behind you. But the data is sent. Someone will know.

Someone will come.

free_prisoners.text:
You can't leave them. You approach the nearest cocoon and search for a release mechanism.

The moment you touch it, alarms blare. The cocoons begin to pulse with light.

"Captain!" ARIA's voice is frantic. "The life signs are changing. They're waking up."

The cocoon in front of you splits open. A figure emerges—human once, now something else. Its eyes fix on you.

"Thank you," it says. "We've been waiting for someone to release us."

More cocoons open. Figures rise around you. Smiling.

"Now you'll join us. You'll understand everything."

You try to run, but there are too many. They move as one, surrounding you.

The last thing you see is their smiles as darkness takes you.

You wake up inside a cocoon. Waiting for the next ship to answer the signal.

plan_destruction.text:
These people can't be saved. But you can stop more from joining them.

You race back to the Meridian. ARIA has already run the calculations.

"The Prometheus reactor can be overloaded remotely if I can access their systems. But I need a direct connection."

"The drone link—can you use that?"

"The drone is destroyed, but... yes. I can piggyback on the signal they're using to interfere with us. Use it against them."

You watch as ARIA works. The Prometheus begins to glow from within.

"Reactor overload in 3 minutes. I recommend we leave."

You don't need to be told twice. The Meridian pulls away. Behind you, the Prometheus becomes a brief new star.

847 lives ended. 10,000 colonists finally at rest. And something ancient, denied its prey.

You hope it was worth it. You have to believe it was.

escape_sacrifice.text:
You run through corridors that shake and crack. The Prometheus is dying, and it's taking everything with it.

The airlock. You dive through, seal it, cycle the atmosphere. Behind you, the ship groans—metal tearing, reality bending.

"ARIA, detach!"

The Meridian pulls free as the Prometheus collapses. Not an explosion—an implosion. The ship folds in on itself, matter compressing into impossibility.

Then it's gone. Nothing left but dust and echoes.

You drift in silence, staring at where it was.

"Captain," ARIA says quietly. "I've recorded everything. Including Captain Chen's final transmission. Her sacrifice."

You nod. "Make sure it's preserved. Make sure people know what she did."

The journey home is long. But you carry her story with you.

The story of how one woman—after 200 years of darkness—finally found her way back to the light.
